repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - First, Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation and Second and Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Technical Assistance Programs

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program (FRDP 1)had the following ratings:
            unsatisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, modest
            institutional development impact, satisfactory Bank
            performance, and unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The
            Second Fiscal Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP
            11) had the following ratings: unsatisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance The First Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP I), and
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program (FRDP 111) had the
            following ratings: highly unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, negligible institutional development impact,
            highly unsatisfactory Bank performance, and highly
            unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Second Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 11TA) had
            the following ratings: moderately satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, satisfactory Bank performance, and satisfactory
            Borrower performance. The Third Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program TA (FRDP 111TA) had the following
            ratings: unsatisfactory outcome, unevaluable sustainability,
            modest institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and satisfactory Borrower performance. The
            experience in these projects highlights the following
            lessons: (a) incentives within the Bank can motivate unwise
            lending; (b) the region's macroeconomic assessments
            need to have greater realism and consistency; (c)
            policy-based lending in an unstable macroeconomic
            environment is unwise; (d) in promoting reform, the Bank
            needs to take account of the incentives that a program
            creates; and (e) the Bank should structure lending to Malawi
            with more earmarked, targeted aid, and tighter fiduciary controls.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Second Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Credit Project and Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcomes of the Second Fiscal
            Restructuring and Deregulation Program Credit Project and
            related Technical Assistance project are mixed but
            satisfactory with likely sustainability and a satisfactory
            performance by both the Bank and the Government. The
            projects demonstrate the synergy between macroeconomic
            stabilization and structural reforms. Also, careful and
            extensive preparation is a necessary but not sufficient
            condition for execution of complex adjustment. Fiscal
            restructuring and civil services reform should begin with a
            fundamental reconsideration of the role of government
            undertake at the political level. While protecting pro-poor
            fiscal outlays may prevent further deterioration of
            services, it cannot address deep-seated problems of equity,
            efficiency, and quality of public health and education The
            willingness of private domestic or foreign enterprises to
            invest in privatized state enterprises in a small poor
            country lacking an established record of good management
            cannot be taken for granted.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Second Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Fiscal Restructuring and
            Deregulation Program Technical Assistance Project supports
            policy reforms to accelerate economic growth and poverty
            reduction and technical assistance to help implement policy
            reforms launched by the government of Malawi since 1994.
            This credit improves public expenditure management and
            promotes private sector development; helps meet the balance
            of payments financing requirements that Malawi faces this
            year, which have increased due to a sharp fall in export
            earnings; and implements policy reforms by maintaining
            economic stability and mitigating the transitional costs of
            adjustment. The Credit's financing for technical
            support, training, and equipment will specifically 1)
            implement the medium term expenditure framework, auditing
            and reviewing the development budget, reforming expenditure
            control procedures and systems; 2) evaluate the impact of
            structural reforms on Malawi's economy, in particular
            by examining the effects of liberalizing trade and exchange
            rate policy on manufacturing, and liberalizing agriculture
            production and trade on the agriculture sector; and 3)
            develop the agenda for the next round of macroeconomic and
            sectoral policy reforms through research into further
            constraints to growth. The Credit will be disbursed--under
            the revised procedures--against satisfactory implementation
            of the adjustment program and not tied to any specific purchases.
